properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for West and South Gippsland.

  • Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce large hailstones, damaging winds and heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding over the next several hours in parts of the West and South Gippsland and Central districts.
  • Locations which may be affected include Wonthaggi.
Be aware of potential hazards caused by the severe thunderstorm, including floodwater, debris, trees down and fallen powerlines.

What you should do: 

  • Park your car undercover and away from trees.
  • Stay inside if conditions outside appear dangerous.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.
If you are driving:
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater.
  • Be aware of road hazards such as mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • For road closure information, check the VicTraffic website, contact your local council or call VicRoads (13 11 70).
Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. 
For severe weather related emergency assistance from the SES, phone 132 500.
Impacts in your area:

The potential impacts of thunderstorms in your area include:
  • Building damage
  • Fallen power lines
  • Fallen trees and branches
  • Dangerous road conditions
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 07:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicstorms)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Cherrypool, the south-western part of Brimpaen and the northern part of the Black Range State Forest
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cherrypool, the south-western part of Brimpaen and the northern part of the Black Range State Forest.

  • This Advice replaces the previous Advice message issued at 10.21am.
  • There is a bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Victoria Valley (Bullawin) is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters have been able to slow the spread of fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Operational burning continues today which may generate smoke and visible active fire. 
Community Newsletter - For further information please access the Community Newsletter here. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
Smoke:
Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.


Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway remains closed between Horsham and Cavendish.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 03/02/2025 02:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

You must monitor conditions and be ready to act. - Operational burning continues today which may generate smoke and visible active fire. Community Newsletter - For further information please access the Community Newsletter here. There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Nurcoung. 
  • There is a bushfire at Little Desert National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Little Desert in a south-easterly direction towards Goroke-Nurcoung Rd.
  • The fire is spreading quickly and may impact private properties in the area.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • You should leave travelling south towards Goroke. 
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
  • Nhill-Harrow Rd is closed between Mill Swamp Lane and Pilgrim Rd.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 08:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Fire Minimay - Diggers Lane, Minimay. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 10:08am 28 January. 
  • Residents are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks including hazardous trees. Do not walk, drive or park near fire affected trees. 
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area:
  • Diggers Lane remains closed. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for South West Victoria.
  • A particularly severe storm to the west of Hamilton is likely to be producing large hailstones.
  • Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce large hailstones, damaging winds and heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding in the warning area over the next several hours. Locations which may be affected include Hamilton, Colac and Geelong.
Be aware of potential hazards caused by the severe thunderstorm, including floodwater, debris, damaged buildings, trees down and fallen powerlines.
What you should do: 

  • Park your car undercover and away from trees.
  • Stay inside if conditions outside appear dangerous.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.
If you are driving:
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater.
  • Be aware of road hazards such as mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • For road closure information, check the VicTraffic website, contact your local council or call VicRoads (13 11 70).
Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. 
For severe weather related emergency assistance from the SES, phone 132 500.
Impacts in your area:

The potential impacts of thunderstorms in your area include:
  • Fallen power lines
  • Fallen trees and branches
  • Flash flooding
  • Overflowing drains and gutters
  • Damage to vehicles
  • Flooding in properties and homes
  • Dangerous road conditions
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 07:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicstorms)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Rocklands, Vasey.
  • There is a bushfire at Vasey that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Vasey in an easterly direction towards Rocklands Reservoir.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 

This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 09:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Threat is Reduced following the bushfire at Little Desert National Park. 
  • This Advice message replaces the advice message issued at 6.52 pm Friday 31 January 2025.
  • The bushfire in the Little Desert National Park is now contained.
  • Fire crews will continue to patrol the fire, blacking out hotspots and reinforcing the containment line. 
  • Surrounding communities may continue to see smoke from this fire.
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
Impacts in your area:
  • Emergency services will still be active at this fire. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.  

This will be the final message issued for this fire. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Brimpaen, Wartook, Zumsteins. 
  • The bushfire that started in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks is not yet under control. 
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 10.46pm, 01st February 2025.
  • Fire crews are actively working on this fire, managing hazardous trees, blacking out hot spots and consolidating containment lines.


The threat is reduced, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway remains closed between Horsham and Cavendish.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
Community Newsletter
For further information, please access the Community Newsletter here.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.   

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 10:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park (Bullawin) is not yet under control.
  • Crews continue to actively work on managing hazardous trees, black out the edge of the fire and extinguish hot spots. 
Community Newsletter
For further information, please access the Community Newsletter here.

The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham and Cavendish.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • A relief centre is open daily from 9:00am to 7:00pm at Hamilton Performing Arts Centre, 113 Brown Street, Hamilton. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 10:00 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Balmoral, Rocklands, Vasey.

  • There is a bushfire at Vasey that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Vasey in an easterly direction towards Rocklands Reservoir. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This message is for people camping on the western side of Rocklands Reservoir, north of Yarramyljup Road.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 08:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au

properties.text:
EMERGENCY WARNING - BUSHFIRE - Take Shelter Now
Incident Location: Vasey
Issue Date: Sunday 02 February 2025, 06:16 pm
Next Update: Sunday 02 February 2025, 08:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36226/moreinfo

This Emergency Warning is being issued for Balmoral, Rocklands, Vasey.

- There is a bushfire at Vasey that is not yet under control.
- The bushfire is travelling from Vasey in an easterly direction towards Rocklands Reservoir. 
- This fire is threatening homes and lives.
- It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now. 
- This message is for people camping on the western side of Rocklands Reservoir, north of Yarramyljup Road.


        You are in danger and need   to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take   shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: Glenisla, Hynes, and the eastern side of Rocklands.
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Glenisla, Hynes, and the eastern side of Rocklands.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued at 3.14pm, 01 February 2025.
  • The bushfire in Grampians National Park  - Victoria Range (Bullawin) is not yet under control. 
  • If conditions are favourable, crews may burn out any unburnt areas along the edge of the Grampians National Park either side of the Victoria Range to build containment lines. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Henty Highway remains closed between Horsham and Cavendish.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (https://traffic.transport.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Relief Centre
  • A relief centre is open daily from 9:00am to 7:00pm at Hamilton Performing Arts Centre, 113 Brown Street, Hamilton. 
Community Newsletter - For further information please access the Community Newsletter here. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 03/02/2025 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Mirranatwa. 
  • There is a bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin) that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Grampians National Park in a southerly direction. It has crossed Red Hills Rd and heading towards Jensens Rd. 
  • Firefighters are actively working on this fire.

Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • Emergency Relief Centre -  Hamilton Performing Arts Centre, 113 Brown Street, Hamilton.  Open daily from 9:00am to 7:00pm, OR
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • You should leave using towards Dunkeld.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham and Cavendish.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 09:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Southern area of the Grampians National Park
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for smoke and ash in the Southern area of the Grampians National Park.
  • Smoke and ash from bushfires and burning out operations in the Grampians National Park is drifting in a southerly and south-westerly direction over a large area including Coleraine, Hamilton, Penshurst, Dunkeld, Glenthompson and other communities further south and south westerly. 
  • Smoke and ash can travel long distances and may be experienced in a much larger area than indicated by this message. 
There is no immediate threat to the community, however you should limit smoke exposure if possible and protect your health.
What you should do:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last smoke message issued.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire.
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill is now Under Control.
  • This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued 21 January.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
Park Closure:
The Grampians National Park is closed to visitors, however Halls Gap township and the Grampians Tourist Road from Halls Gap to Dunkeld are both open. 

For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or call in to Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 
Recovery and resilience
If you have been or may be impacted by bushfire, it is understandable if you are feeling concerned and experiencing a mix of strong mental, emotional or physical reactions right now. For emergency relief information during major incidents, call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226 or visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief
Impacts in your area: 
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 04/02/2025 03:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed Incident Location: Grampians National Park Issue Date: Tuesday 28 January 2025, 03:10 pm Next Update: Tuesday 04 February 2025, 03:20 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36001/moreinfo This Advice message is being issued for areas of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. - The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill is now Under Control. - This Advice message replaces the Advice message issued 21 January. - Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines. - Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible. Park Closure: The Grampians National Park is closed to visitors, however Halls Gap township and the Grampians Tourist Road from Halls Gap to Dunkeld are both open. For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or call in to Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap. There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Big Cord, Strachans, Victoria Point, Victoria Valley
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Big Cord, Strachans, Victoria Point, Victoria Valley. 

  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 1.38 pm, due to increased fire activity.
  • It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave. 
  • There is a bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin). The bushfire is not yet under control.
Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.
What you should do:
  • Monitor the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.
  • Protect yourself and your family.
  • If you are not prepared, leave now. Dont wait until it is too late - leave early. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If you are leaving, pack: 
  • Cash 
  • Clothing for three days 
  • Medicine for three days 
  • Phone and chargers 
  • Toiletries 
  • Important documents 
  • Meaningful items and photos 
  • Pet essentials, including leash and carriers.
Check on your neighbours if it is safe.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 

Where to go:
  • Friends or family away from the fire. 
  • Consider roads may become busy closer to the time of impact. 
  • Emergency Relief CentreHamilton Performing Arts Centre, 113 Brown Street, Hamilton.  Open daily from 9:00am to 7:00pm

Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham & Cavendish. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Community Newsletter - For further information please access the Community Newsletter here. 

Grampians National Park
  • The Southern Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park is closed due to the current weather conditions, which are causing unpredictable fire activity.
  • This includes Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks.
  • The Grampians Tourist Road from Dunkeld to Halls Gap is currently open.
Smoke:
Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 02/02/2025 06:50 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
WATCH & ACT - BUSHFIRE - Prepare to Leave
Incident Location: Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin)
Issue Date: Sunday 02 February 2025, 02:51 pm
Next Update: Sunday 02 February 2025, 06:50 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36202/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Big Cord, Strachans, Victoria Point, Victoria Valley. 

- This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 1.38 pm, due to increased fire activity.
- It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave. 

- There is a bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin). The bushfire is not yet under control.


        Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are   ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.

properties.sourceTitle: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for LARGE HAILSTONES, DAMAGING WINDS and HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.name: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for LARGE HAILSTONES, DAMAGING WINDS and HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.webHeadline:
Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce large hailstones, damaging winds and heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding in the warning area over the next several hours. Locations which may be affected include Horsham, Stawell, Warracknabeal, Hamilton, Ararat and Geelong.


Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the West and South Gippsland district and the warning for this district is CANCELLED.


In fire affected areas heavy rainfall increases the risk of debris flows, runoff may carry ash, soil, rocks and vegetation onto roads and tracks and into waterways.

124 km/h wind gust was recorded at Mt Gellibrand (west of Geelong) at 5:23 pm.

2cm hailstones were observed at Tootgarook around 2:30 pm.

properties.sourceTitle: Severe Thunderstorm Warning - Melbourne Area for DAMAGING WINDS, LARGE HAILSTONES and HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.name: Severe Thunderstorm Warning - Melbourne Area for DAMAGING WINDS, LARGE HAILSTONES and HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.webHeadline:
The Bureau of Meteorology warns that, at 6:30 pm, a severe thunderstorm likely to produce damaging winds, large hailstones and heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding was detected near Geelong City and the area west of Lara. This thunderstorm is moving towards the southeast. It is forecast to affect Lara, Ocean Grove and waters off Geelong City by 7:00 pm and northern parts of the Bellarine Peninsula, Point Lonsdale and Queenscliff by 7:30 pm.


124 km/h wind gust was recorded at Mt Gellibrand (west of Geelong) at 5:23 pm.
2cm hailstones were observed at Tootgarook around 2:30 pm.

properties.location: Port Phillip waters, Mornington Peninsula and Geelong and Bellarine Peninsula
